head.title: With Soft Money, Hard Choices; Punish Scofflaws

hedline.hl1: With Soft Money, Hard Choices; Punish Scofflaws

abstract.p: Carroll D French letter says fines and repayments of illegal campaign contributions are likely to become regarded as simply additional campaign expenses (Dec 2 editorial)

block.p: ''Illegal Use of Soft Money'' (editorial, Dec. 2) refers to the 1996 Presidential campaign as ''one of the most corrupt in modern history'' and asserts that President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole violated the campaign spending laws. How would you punish such violations in the future? Fines and repayments seem likely to become regarded as simply additional campaign expenses.

''Illegal Use of Soft Money'' (editorial, Dec. 2) refers to the 1996 Presidential campaign as ''one of the most corrupt in modern history'' and asserts that President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole violated the campaign spending laws. How would you punish such violations in the future? Fines and repayments seem likely to become regarded as simply additional campaign expenses.

Jail terms might work for unsuccessful candidates, but removal of elected officials from office itself would violate the democratic election process. Do you believe that motions of censure would make the politicians shake in their boots?
CARROLL D. FRENCH Alstead, N.H., Dec. 2, 1998
